Cartan-Karlhede Algorithm

API Reference

This section provides detailed information about the API of the Cartan-Karlhede algorithm implementation.

Metric Module

Metric and frame definitions for the Cartan-Karlhede algorithm.

class cartan_karlhede.metric.Metric(components, coordinates, name='Unnamed Metric')[source]

Bases: object

Class representing a spacetime metric.

The metric is a symmetric rank 2 tensor with Lorentzian signature that defines the geometry of the spacetime in general relativity. In local coordinates, the metric is represented by a matrix of components :math:`g_{mu

u}`.

According to the Cartan-Karlhede algorithm, the equivalence of two metrics can be determined by comparing the functional relations between the components of the curvature tensor and its covariant derivatives in appropriate frames.

Attributes:

components (Matrix): Symbolic matrix of metric components :math:`g_{mu

u}`

coordinates (List[Symbol]): List of coordinate symbols name (str): Optional name for the metric dim (int): Dimension of the spacetime inverse (Matrix): Inverse metric components :math:`g^{mu

u}`

References:

Mergulhão, T. M., & Batista, C. (2023). “On the Equivalence of Spacetimes, the Cartan-Karlhede Algorithm”. Section 2.

Initialize a metric.

Args:

components: Symbolic matrix of metric components :math:`g_{mu

u}`

coordinates: List of coordinate symbols name: Optional name for the metric

Parameters:

  • components (MutableDenseMatrix)

  • coordinates (List[Symbol])

  • name (str)

christoffel_symbols()[source]

Compute the Christoffel symbols of the metric.

The Christoffel symbols are defined as:

\[\Gamma^{\lambda}_{\mu\nu} = \frac{1}{2} g^{\lambda\sigma} (\partial_{\mu} g_{\nu\sigma} + \partial_{\nu} g_{\mu\sigma} - \partial_{\sigma} g_{\mu\nu})\]
Returns:

Dictionary mapping (μ, ν, λ) → Γ^λ_μν

Return type:

Dict[Tuple[int, int, int], Expr]

References

Mergulhão, T. M., & Batista, C. (2023). “On the Equivalence of Spacetimes, the Cartan-Karlhede Algorithm”. Equation (2).

riemann_tensor()[source]

Compute the Riemann curvature tensor of the metric.

The Riemann curvature tensor is defined as:

\[R^{\alpha}_{\beta\mu\nu} = \partial_{\nu} \Gamma^{\alpha}_{\beta\mu} - \partial_{\mu} \Gamma^{\alpha}_{\beta\nu} + \Gamma^{\alpha}_{\sigma\nu} \Gamma^{\sigma}_{\beta\mu} - \Gamma^{\alpha}_{\sigma\mu} \Gamma^{\sigma}_{\beta\nu}\]
Returns:

Dictionary mapping (α, β, μ, ν) → R^α_βμν

Return type:

Dict[Tuple[int, int, int, int], Expr]

References

Mergulhão, T. M., & Batista, C. (2023). “On the Equivalence of Spacetimes, the Cartan-Karlhede Algorithm”. Equation (3).

ricci_tensor()[source]

Compute the Ricci tensor of the metric.

Returns:

Dictionary mapping (μ, ν) -> R_μν

Return type:

Dict[Tuple[int, int], Expr]

ricci_scalar()[source]

Compute the Ricci scalar of the metric.

Returns:

The Ricci scalar R

Return type:

Expr

weyl_tensor()[source]

Compute the Weyl tensor of the metric (in dimension ≥ 3).

Returns:

Dictionary mapping (μ, ν, ρ, σ) -> C_μνρσ

Return type:

Dict[Tuple[int, int, int, int], Expr]

class cartan_karlhede.metric.LorentzFrame(metric, frame_vectors, eta=None)[source]

Bases: object

Class representing a Lorentz frame for a metric.

Initialize a Lorentz frame.

Parameters:

  • metric (Metric) – The metric for which this is a frame

  • frame_vectors (List[MutableDenseMatrix]) – List of frame vector fields as column matrices

  • eta (MutableDenseMatrix | None) – The constant frame metric (default: Minkowski)

dual_frame()[source]

Compute the dual frame 1-forms.

Returns:

List of dual frame 1-forms as row matrices

Return type:

List[MutableDenseMatrix]

curvature_components()[source]

Compute the components of the Riemann tensor in the frame.

Returns:

Dictionary mapping (a, b, c, d) -> R_abcd

Return type:

Dict[Tuple[int, int, int, int], Expr]

curvature_derivative(order=1)[source]

Compute the components of the derivative of the Riemann tensor in the frame.

Parameters:

order (int) – The order of the derivative to compute

Returns:

Dictionary mapping multi-indices to derivative components

Return type:

Dict[Tuple, Expr]

class cartan_karlhede.metric.NullFrame(metric, l_vector, n_vector, m_vector, mbar_vector)[source]

Bases: object

Class representing a null frame for a 4D Lorentzian metric.

Initialize a null frame.

Parameters:

  • metric (Metric) – The metric for which this is a frame

  • l_vector (MutableDenseMatrix) – The first null vector field (ℓ)

  • n_vector (MutableDenseMatrix) – The second null vector field (n)

  • m_vector (MutableDenseMatrix) – The complex null vector field (m)

  • mbar_vector (MutableDenseMatrix) – The complex conjugate of m (m̄)

weyl_scalars()[source]

Compute the Weyl scalars for the null frame.

Returns:

Dictionary mapping scalar names to their values

Return type:

Dict[str, Expr]

petrov_type()[source]

Determine the Petrov type of the spacetime.

Returns:

String indicating the Petrov type (I, II, D, III, N, or O)

Return type:

str

curvature_components()[source]

Compute the components of the Riemann tensor in the null frame.

Returns:

Dictionary mapping (a, b, c, d) -> R_abcd where a,b,c,d index the null frame

Return type:

Dict[Tuple[int, int, int, int], Expr]

curvature_derivative(order=1)[source]

Compute the components of the derivative of the Riemann tensor in the null frame.

Parameters:

order (int) – The order of the derivative to compute

Returns:

Dictionary mapping multi-indices to derivative components

Return type:

Dict[Tuple, Expr]

Algorithm Module

Implementation of the Cartan-Karlhede algorithm for spacetime equivalence.

cartan_karlhede.algorithm.find_functionally_independent_components(components, coordinates)[source]

Find the number of functionally independent components.

Parameters:

  • components (Dict[Tuple, Expr]) – Dictionary of components

  • coordinates (List[Symbol]) – List of coordinate symbols

Returns:

Tuple of (number of functionally independent components, list of independent expressions)

Return type:

Tuple[int, List[Expr]]

cartan_karlhede.algorithm.analyze_metric(metric, frame, max_order=3)[source]

Analyze a metric using the Cartan-Karlhede algorithm.

Parameters:

  • metric (Metric) – The metric to analyze

  • frame (LorentzFrame | NullFrame) – The frame to use for the analysis

  • max_order (int) – Maximum derivative order to consider

Returns:

Dictionary containing analysis results

Return type:

Dict

cartan_karlhede.algorithm.compare_metrics(metric1, frame1, metric2, frame2, max_order=3)[source]

Compare two metrics to determine if they are equivalent.

Parameters:

  • metric1 (Metric) – First metric

  • frame1 (LorentzFrame | NullFrame) – Frame for the first metric

  • metric2 (Metric) – Second metric

  • frame2 (LorentzFrame | NullFrame) – Frame for the second metric

  • max_order (int) – Maximum derivative order to consider

Returns:

Tuple of (are equivalent, explanation)

Return type:

Tuple[bool, str]

cartan_karlhede.algorithm.find_coordinate_transformation(metric1, metric2, transformation_ansatz)[source]

Find a coordinate transformation between two metrics.

Parameters:

  • metric1 (Metric) – First metric

  • metric2 (Metric) – Second metric

  • transformation_ansatz (Dict[Symbol, Expr]) – Initial guess for the transformation

Returns:

Dictionary mapping coordinates of metric1 to expressions in terms of metric2 coordinates

Return type:

Dict[Symbol, Expr] | None

Create the 3D example metrics from the paper.

Returns:

List of the five 3D metrics discussed in the paper

Create null frames for the Schwarzschild metrics.

Parameters:

  • metric – Standard Schwarzschild metric

  • alt_metric – Alternative Schwarzschild metric

Returns:

Tuple of (frame for standard metric, frame for alternative metric)

Create Lorentz frames for the 3D example metrics.

metrics – List of 3D metrics

List of frames for the metrics
